title: How to Protect Bedding Plants from Frost

steps.headline: Follow your local weather forecasts.
steps.description: This procedure will help you determine if you need to protect your bedding plants from frost at any given time, especially during seasonal and temperature changes.

steps.headline: Pack mulch around your bedding plants to retain heat and moisture.
steps.description:
Mulch may prevent the ground surrounding your bedding plants from freezing. Mulch can be used in the form of straw, loose tree leaves, tree bark, or pine needles. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/07\/Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/0\/07\/Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/aid1640788-v4-728px-Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Water your bedding plants before it becomes dark outside.
steps.description:
The wet soil will raise the humidity levels in the area surrounding your plants and help them retain heat. You may want to water your bedding plants up to 1 or 2 days before freezing conditions are expected. If you water your plants during freezing temperatures, they may freeze immediately. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c0\/Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/c\/c0\/Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/aid1640788-v4-728px-Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":344,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"544","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Use a soil thermometer to check the temperature of the ground.
Cover your bedding plants when the soil temperature is below freezing.
Remove the covers from your bedding plants after all frost has thawed.
steps.description: This procedure will expose your plants to fresh air and prevent your plants from overheating in the sun.

text:
Follow your local weather forecasts. This procedure will help you determine if you need to protect your bedding plants from frost at any given time, especially during seasonal and temperature changes. Pack mulch around your bedding plants to retain heat and moisture. Mulch may prevent the ground surrounding your bedding plants from freezing. Mulch can be used in the form of straw, loose tree leaves, tree bark, or pine needles. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/07/Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/0/07/Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/aid1640788-v4-728px-Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Water your bedding plants before it becomes dark outside. The wet soil will raise the humidity levels in the area surrounding your plants and help them retain heat. You may want to water your bedding plants up to 1 or 2 days before freezing conditions are expected. If you water your plants during freezing temperatures, they may freeze immediately. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c0/Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/c/c0/Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/aid1640788-v4-728px-Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":344,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"544","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Use a soil thermometer to check the temperature of the ground. This will help you determine if the ground is cold enough to cause your bedding plants to freeze. Purchase a soil thermometer from any retail store that specializes in gardening products. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/90/Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-4Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/9/90/Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-4Bullet1.jpg/aid1640788-v4-728px-Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Insert the soil thermometer into the ground between 10 and 15 cm (4 and 6 inches) to determine its temperature. Refer to the instructions provided by the soil thermometer's manufacturer to make sure it has been inserted properly for an accurate reading. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b2/Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-4Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/b/b2/Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-4Bullet2.jpg/aid1640788-v4-728px-Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":346,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"547","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Cover your bedding plants when the soil temperature is below freezing. Freezing temperatures are below 0 degrees Celsius (0 degrees Fahrenheit). You may also want to cover your bedding plants if the temperature is slightly above freezing levels in the event the temperature continues to drop overnight. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e5/Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/e/e5/Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/aid1640788-v4-728px-Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Place layers of horticultural fleece over your bedding plants. Horticultural fleece is insulating material that will keep your plants warm during frost conditions but still expose them to air, rain, and light. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-5Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-5Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/7/76/Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-5Bullet2.jpg/aid1640788-v4-728px-Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-5Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":351,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"556","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Alternative forms of bedding plant covers are plastic tarps, newspapers, cardboard, bed linens, or similar types of light materials. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9b/Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-5Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-5Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/9/9b/Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-5Bullet3.jpg/aid1640788-v4-728px-Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-5Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Use heavy objects such as stones or jars to weigh down the sides of the protective covering. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3f/Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-5Bullet4.jpg/v4-460px-Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-5Bullet4.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/3/3f/Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-5Bullet4.jpg/aid1640788-v4-728px-Protect-Bedding-Plants-from-Frost-Step-5Bullet4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":352,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"557","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Remove the covers from your bedding plants after all frost has thawed. This procedure will expose your plants to fresh air and prevent your plants from overheating in the sun.
